title: CPR for Adults
summary: Step-by-step guide for performing cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) on adults who are unresponsive and not breathing normally.

steps.title: Ensure Safety and Check Responsiveness
steps.description: Check the scene for safety. Tap the person's shoulders firmly and shout 'Are you okay?' If unresponsive, call 911 immediately or have someone else do it. Request an AED if available.

steps.title: Position the Person
steps.description: Place the person on their back on a firm, flat surface. Tilt their head back by lifting the chin to open the airway. Check for breathing for no more than 10 seconds.

steps.title: Perform Chest Compressions
steps.description: Place the heel of one hand on the center of the chest between the nipples. Place your other hand on top, interlacing fingers. Press hard and fast at least 2 inches deep at a rate of 100-120 compressions per minute. Allow complete chest recoil between compressions.

steps.title: Give Rescue Breaths
steps.description: After 30 compressions, open the airway using head-tilt, chin-lift. Pinch the nose closed and make a seal over their mouth. Give 2 breaths, each lasting 1 second, watching for chest rise.

steps.title: Continue CPR Cycles
steps.description: Continue with 30 chest compressions followed by 2 rescue breaths. Repeat until emergency services arrive or the person starts breathing normally. If an AED arrives, follow its voice prompts.

warnings: Do not perform CPR if the person is conscious and breathing normally
CPR can cause rib fractures - this is normal and should not stop you from continuing
If you're untrained in rescue breaths, provide continuous chest compressions only
whenToSeekHelp: Always call 911 immediately when someone is unresponsive
Continue CPR until professional help arrives
If multiple rescuers are present, switch every 2 minutes to prevent fatigue
preventionTips: Learn to recognize signs of cardiac arrest early
Take a certified CPR course to improve your skills
Know the location of AEDs in your workplace and community
